div.p: A CENTURY OF SACRED DISTICKS OR, RELIGION IN VERSE,

q.p: The braveſt thing is a Religious Life.

div.p: OXFORD, Printed by Leon. Lichfield, Printer to the Univerſity, for John Barksdale Bookſeller in Cirenceſter, 1685.

div.head: To His Noble Friend.
div.l: TO preſcribe to theſe Verſes your fair Name,
Altho but one clean Sheet, it were no ſhame.
Till Something of more Learning I ſhall have,
You ſhall be Nameleſs. Yet, Religion's brave.

div.head: One Century OF SACRED DISTICKS, OR, Religion in verſe.

l.hi: IN theſe plain Verſes I have no other ends,
But to edify my Self, and my good Friends

lg.head: I. Accounts.
lg.l: HOW ſuddenly may I be call'd away!
'Tis good to make Accounts up every day.

lg.head: II. Acceptance.
lg.l: Lord! Be Thou ſtill the ſame. Thou gracious art
And wilt accept a broken contrite heart.

lg.head: III. Grace.
lg.l: I fear not, when my Heart by God is view'd,
As by the Grace of Chriſt is is renew'd.

lg.head: IV. Perſecution.
lg.l: To perſecute is to hurt the Innocent:
To proſecute is of the Guilty meant.

lg.head: V. Gravity.
lg.l: Let Grave men take ſo much Autority,
As to correct the faults i'th' company.

lg.head: VI. Oaths.
lg.l: Vain Swearing, if you hear; to your ſelf look,
You be not guilty: Give it a rebuke.

lg.head: VIII. Luſt.
lg.l: Some think they are honeſt, if they do not act;
Ill Thoughts and Eyes are guilty of the Fact.

lg.head: VIII. Company.
lg.l: Fairly depart, if there be two, or one
Quarrel-ſome Fellow. Better be alone.

lg.head: IX. The Lye.
lg.l: If it be ſaid, you lye: you quarrel and fight:
If told, you Swear: of that you make but light.

lg.head: X. Rules.
lg.l: When you do think or read of ſome good Rule,
Bind it in Rhythm, and put thy ſelf to School.

lg.head: XI. Conſpiracy.
lg.l: Let Good men make a new Conſpiracy,
To amend this Ages Immorality.

lg.head: XII. Again.
lg.l: To conſpire in good Actions, is a Thing
Will pleaſe our God, and not diſpleaſe our King.

lg.head: XIII. The Fight.
lg.l: Single men boldly are gone out, to fight
'Gainſt Sin and Satan. Let their Force unite.

lg.head: XIV. Fugitives.
lg.l: Little's the Hope of complete Victory,
When ſome of us turn to the Enemy.

lg.head: XV. Subjects.
lg.l: Why don't all Subjects their good King obey?
They are proud, and wou'd be their own maſters, They.

lg.head: XVI. Money.
lg.l: You do love Money. Yes: tis true you ſay.
But 'tis not to lay up, but give and pay.

lg.head: XVII. Again.
lg.l: You give too much? No: what I gave,
That in the better Senſe I have.

lg.head: XVIII. Repayment.
lg.l: What you do borrow, take care to repay:
Not borrow ag • in, unleſs you keep your day.

lg.head: XIX. Night.
lg.l: Awaking, baniſh luſt; and think upon
What good work on the next day muſt be done.

lg.head: XX. Again.
lg.l: Lying a Bed the Winter Nights ſo long,
Praiſe ye Gods loving kindneſs in a Song.

lg.head: XXI. Sacred Diſticks.
lg.l: Among your Diſticks, thoſe are beſt of all,
Which contain Obſervations Scriptural.

lg.head: XXII. Gluttons. Pſal.
lg.l: What's ſaid of bloudy men, is true, no doubt,
Of Gluttons: Half their days they live not out.

lg.head: XXIII. Diet.
lg.l: A Diet, ſimple, ſpare, not exceſſive,
Will keep thee in good health, and long alive.

lg.head: XXIV. Hoſpitality.
lg.l: I praiſe the good Houſe-Keeper. God will bleſs
The Hoſpitable. Shun Inordinateneſs.

lg.head: XXV. Abſtinent.
lg.l: The Abſtinent will have the more to give;
With what they ſpare the needy they relieve.

lg.head: XXVI. Parſon.
lg.l: Not only give them, that come to your door;
But ſend your Corn and Money to the poor.

lg.head: XXVII. Rich.
lg.l: The Rich have a Temptation to exceed:
In great Proſperity then take great heed.

lg.head: XXVIII. Sayings.
lg.l: Arch-Biſhop Sheldon's: Do well, and be merry.
Old Biſhop Hacket's: Serve God, and be cheary.

lg.head: XXIX. Entertainment.
lg.l: My Learned Friend, inſtead of Second-Courſe,
Let us have ſome Religious Diſcourſe.

lg.head: XXX. Old Age.
lg.l: Your Seventy years are paſt: You are alive,
To bring forth more Fruit now, at Seventy Five.

lg.head: XXXI. Forms.
lg.l: With bare External Forms be not content:
Joyn unto them an Heart Obedient.

lg.head: XXXII. Life and Light. Pſal.
lg.l: The Well-Spring of True Life, Lord, is in Thee:
And in thy Light thy Servant Light ſhall ſee.

lg.head: XXXIV. God. Pſal.
lg.l: Thy Mercy reacheth to the Heavens ſo high:
Thy Judgments, Lord, in the great Deep do lye.

lg.head: XXXV. Preacher
lg.l: Let not a Preacher overmuch complain:
To win Souls is great pleaſure, is great gain.

lg.head: XXXVII. Earthly.
lg.l: Could we in Earthly Seats for ever reſt,
'Twere ſome pretence for feathering our Neſt.

lg.head: XXXVIII. Morstua, mors Chriſti. &c.
lg.l: Thy death, Chriſt's Death, the world's fraud, pains of hell,
Glory of Heaven; Theſe five remember well.

lg.head: XXX • X. Sustine and Abstine. Epict.
lg.l: Philoſophy in ſhort: Hardſhips ſuſtain
Of Virtue: From delights of Vice abſtain.

lg.head: XL. Fear.
lg.l: Fear is a Virtue: Be not thou fearleſs
Of that dark Pit, from whence is no regreſs.

lg.head: XLI. Servant.
lg.l: I'm ſometimes angry with my Servant: then
Am pleas'd, becauſe he anſwers not agen.

lg.head: XLII. Philo of Moſes.
lg.l: Forty days Moſes on the Mount did lye,
Faſting, becauſe he heard Heavens Melody.

lg.head: XLIII. Heaven.
lg.l: The Labour of our whole life is much leſs,
Infinitely leſs, than Heavens Happineſs.

lg.head: XLIV. My God. Pſal.
lg.l: Lord, I'm thy Servant, Thou haſt choſen me:
Thou art my God, and I have choſen thee.

lg.head: XLV. Caſſander.
lg.l: New Liturgy, this peaceable Divine
Did, out of David's Pſalter, once deſign.

lg.head: XLVI. Manſion.
lg.l: Friends, would you have a Manſion above?
Think oft, and ſpeak of Heav'n, and live in Love.

lg.head: XLVII. Scripture.
lg.l: Let ſimple ones read Scripture, but decline
The darker places, till the Guide doth ſhine.

lg.head: XLVIII. Pariſh.
lg.l: The Miniſter, if learn'd, and of good life,
Does well deſerve his Pariſhes belief.

lg.head: XLIX. Friend.
lg.l: I think you are my Friend: I know you are,
If you will have of my poor Soul a care.

lg.head: L. Humility.
lg.l: Humility's a Jewel. If you have ey'd
Any of your good deeds beware of Pride.

lg.head: LI. Hope.
lg.l: Ah me! That worldly care creates me fear,
Having a hope of better things ſo near.

lg.head: LII. Return.
lg.l: Had I not been forſaken, I'd not find,
At Gods Return, ſuch comfort in my mind.

lg.head: LIII. Charity.
lg.l: Give me a Rule to live well by.

lg.head: LIV. Chaſtiſement.
lg.l: In thy Chaſtiſements, if ſevere thou art:
Lord! Never puniſh me a hard Heart.

lg.head: LV. Diſconſolate.
lg.l: For the diſconſolate, pity it will win,
If you remember, This your Caſe has bin.

lg.head: LVI. Carnal.
lg.l: They that themſelves in fleſhly pleaſures roul
Know not the ſorrows of a Penitent Soul.

lg.head: LVII. God.
lg.l: Chriſtian, when thou feeleſt his ſmart Rod,
Know that ſweet pleaſures alſo are from God.

lg.head: LVIII. Recompenſe.
lg.l: Preſent Affliction is but a ſhort pain:
Joys everlaſting, are the future gain.

lg.head: LIX. Guard.
lg.l: The Godly have, as other, this reward.
They have, by God's appointment th' Angels Guard.

lg.head: LX. Grave.
lg.l: Pray, when you viſit the deceaſed's Grave,
We a Reſurrection to life may have.

lg.head: LXI. Company.
lg.l: When I'm in Company; I gladly wou'd,
From them receive, and do to them ſome good

lg.head: LXII. Dayly Prayer.
lg.l: To pray at Church alone, don't you forbear:
Chriſt and his Angels will be with you there.

lg.head: LXIV. People.
lg.l: Neighbours your Books to Church on Sundays bring
Attend the Miniſter in every thing.

lg.head: LXV. Again.
lg.l: The face of our Aſſemblies fair wou'd be,
Would people come to good Conformity.

lg.head: LXVI. Children.
lg.l: God will now bleſs us, Meek Melanchthon ſaid,
When at a School he ſaw the Children pray'd.

lg.head: LXVII. Again.
lg.l: Children may be more gracious, every one,
By the good Biſhops Confirmation.

lg.head: LXVIII. Breeding.
lg.l: Look to your Children, Friends? If they're ill bred
Better they had, as ſoon as born, been dead.

lg.head: LXIX. Reverence.
lg.l: Where's little Reverence in the outward part,
I fear there is no Reverence in the Heart.

lg.head: LXX. Whole Duty.
lg.l: The Second Volume of the Duty Whole
Is welcome May't prevail on every Soul!

lg.head: LXXI. Means.
lg.l: The better Means are offer'd to live well,
Ill Life will be more puniſhed in Hell.

lg.head: LXXII. Dreams.
lg.l: With your Black Dreams be never terrify'd,
Their Vanity having ſo often try'd.

lg.head: LXXIII. Examen.
lg.l: When Company is gone, Remember this;
Examine, what you have done, or ſaid amiſs.

lg.head: LXXIV. Thoughts.
lg.l: Repell ill thoughts: Awaking, think upon,
God's mercy and thy ſins, when ſleep is gone.

lg.head: LXXV. Intereſt.
lg.l: Man wou'd be a God to himſelf, apt to intend
Profit and intereſt, as his laſt end.

lg.head: LXXV. Man.
lg.l: Man born again, to whom his Maker's known,
Know's well, that he is God's, more than his own.

lg.head: LXXVI. A Friend.
lg.l: Haſt thou a Friend? Value him, To him declare
Thy inmoſt thoughts. A Friend is very rare.

lg.head: LXXVII. Again.
lg.l: Haſt try'd thy Friend? Him in thy Book enroul,
Defend him abſent: 'moniſh him preſent; ſave his ſoul

lg.head: LXXVIII. Enemy.
lg.l: Haſt thou an Enemy? Hath he thee withſtood?
And done ill to thee? O'recome ill with good.

lg.head: LXXIX. Parents.
lg.l: Parents may Glory in their Children, when
By Divine Grace they are become New Men.

lg.head: LXXX. Comfort.
lg.l: Ye Souls dejected, who for Comfort look,
Get you a good Companion, and good Book.

lg.head: LXXXI. Happineſs.
lg.l: What is our Happineſs, ſincere and true?
To be and do, what God wou'd have us be and do.

lg.head: LXXXII. Civility.
lg.l: When e're you meet me, Neighbour, pray afford
Unto me a kind look, and a kind word.

lg.head: LXXXIII. Flattery.
lg.l: To flatter ſinners, and ſay, 'Twill be well;
Is the moſt eaſy Path-way unto Hell.

lg.head: LXXXIV. Correction.
lg.l: To correct Vice in theſe licentious Times,
Some little deal conduce your ſacred Rhymes.

lg.head: LXXXV. Relapſe.
lg.l: Relapſe you may prevent by diligence:
Stand then upon your Watch, till you go hence.

lg.head: LXXXVI. Viſits.
lg.l: At Viſits of Great Perſons ſpeak not much:
Reſpect and Reverence is due to ſuch.

lg.head: LXXXVII. Meekneſs.
lg.l: If you converſe ſometimes with froward men,
Be Meek: there will ariſe no Quarrel then.

lg.head: LXXXVIII. Satan.
lg.l: Sure if the Adverſary do us harm,
'Tis 'cauſe we do'nt our ſelves with firm Faith arm.

lg.head: LXXXIX. Riches.
lg.l: Riches (as wiſe men ſay) have their ſwift Wings,
And leave us deſtitute. Truſt not theſe things.

lg.head: XC. Recovery.
lg.l: Marvelous Change, and Memorable Fate!
Thy Faculties are vivid, faint ſo late.

lg.head: XCI. Gifts.
lg.l: Thy Gifts, with God, will not accepted be,
Nor with Men, if not given Cheerfully.

lg.head: XCII. Portion.
lg.l: For want of Money is Marriage delaid?
Modeſty's the beſt Dowry of a Maid.

lg.head: XCIII. Nurſe.
lg.l: Let not your Infant have an ungodly Nurſe:
All his life-long he is like to be the worſe.

lg.head: XCIV. Preacher.
lg.l: Then a good Preacher does his Pariſh right,
At once when he does profit and delight.

lg.head: XCVI. Preparation.
lg.l: What is your great Concernment? To take care
Of my own Soul, and for my Death prepare.

lg.head: XCVII. Loſs.
lg.l: In idle Talk, vain Sports, and curious Dreſſing,
How many Men and Women loſe a Bleſſing!

lg.head: XCVIII. Inconſiderate.
lg.l: Some enter in the World, and leave the ſame,
Never conſidering to what end they came.

lg.head: XCIX. Good Works.
lg.l: What Works the Reverend Thomas Gouge hath done,
Is well ſet forth by Doctor Tillotſon.

lg.head: C. Good Life.
lg.l: Every great Lady, that on Parkhurſt looks,
May a rare Pattern ſee in Lady Brookes.
